questions.question_text_1: Total utility _________ at (a / an) _________ rate when marginal utility is decreasing but positive.
question_texts: Total utility _________ at (a / an) _________ rate when marginal utility is decreasing but positive.

questions.question_text_1: Statement 1: She prefers bread over ice cream, and sandwiches over bread. Statement 2: She derives 100 utility points from eating a slice of bread.  Which of the two utility theories, viz., the Cardinal Utility Theory (CUT) and the Ordinal Utility Theory (OUT), does each of these statements belong?
question_texts: Statement 1: She prefers bread over ice cream, and sandwiches over bread. Statement 2: She derives 100 utility points from eating a slice of bread.  Which of the two utility theories, viz., the Cardinal Utility Theory (CUT) and the Ordinal Utility Theory (OUT), does each of these statements belong?

questions.question_text_1: “She was hungry and wanted a Dosa. The app on her phone gave her a better price for a plate of Idlis; so she chose Idli over Dosa. She also wanted to buy a printer. However, the cartridge was very expensive, and thus she had to drop the idea of getting a printer.”  The first purchase decision (Dosa/Idli) is a classic example of _______ goods and the second (printer/cartridge) is an example of _________ goods.
question_texts: “She was hungry and wanted a Dosa. The app on her phone gave her a better price for a plate of Idlis; so she chose Idli over Dosa. She also wanted to buy a printer. However, the cartridge was very expensive, and thus she had to drop the idea of getting a printer.”  The first purchase decision (Dosa/Idli) is a classic example of _______ goods and the second (printer/cartridge) is an example of _________ goods.

questions.question_text_1: Assume person X consumes only 2 goods food and books in a month. Also assume that both food and books are normal goods for X. A decrease in the price of food will lead to X’s consumption of books to:
question_texts: Assume person X consumes only 2 goods food and books in a month. Also assume that both food and books are normal goods for X. A decrease in the price of food will lead to X’s consumption of books to:

options.option_text: increase owing to negative income elasticity.

questions.question_text_1: Ram’s toy shop on an e-commerce website was having a dry spell despite him running a price promotion. To boost the sales, he set out a banner on the landing page of the shop that read “Only few hours left for the sale to end!” while he would actually reset the banner every couple of hours. What pricing strategy is Ram is using?
question_texts: Ram’s toy shop on an e-commerce website was having a dry spell despite him running a price promotion. To boost the sales, he set out a banner on the landing page of the shop that read “Only few hours left for the sale to end!” while he would actually reset the banner every couple of hours. What pricing strategy is Ram is using?

questions.question_text_1: See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.

question_texts: See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.
See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.

options.option_text: An increase in Demand will shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will shift the curve D2 towards D1
An increase in Demand will not shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will not shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will not shift the curve D2 towards D1

questions.question_text_1: Consider this hypothetical example: Coca-Cola decreased the price of 300 ml Diet Coke can from INR 40 per can to INR 38. This resulted in consumers buying 7000 cans a week. Before the price drop, consumers bought only 5000 cans a week. In the same week, Pepsi reduced the price of its Black cans by INR 2, which increased the sales of Pepsi Black by a whopping 25%! To add to all the complexity, in the same week, the price of petrol increased by 3%, and that of diesel by 2.5%, resulting in a net decrease in fuel usage by 0.02%. Given all this data, calculate the price elasticity of demand of Diet Coke (round the answer to 2 decimal places).
question_texts: Consider this hypothetical example: Coca-Cola decreased the price of 300 ml Diet Coke can from INR 40 per can to INR 38. This resulted in consumers buying 7000 cans a week. Before the price drop, consumers bought only 5000 cans a week. In the same week, Pepsi reduced the price of its Black cans by INR 2, which increased the sales of Pepsi Black by a whopping 25%! To add to all the complexity, in the same week, the price of petrol increased by 3%, and that of diesel by 2.5%, resulting in a net decrease in fuel usage by 0.02%. Given all this data, calculate the price elasticity of demand of Diet Coke (round the answer to 2 decimal places).

questions.question_text_1: A firm has INR 500000/- as accounts receivable (debtors), while its annual sales turnover is INR 6500000/-. Calculate the firm’s debtor days (round the answer to 2 decimal places).
question_texts: A firm has INR 500000/- as accounts receivable (debtors), while its annual sales turnover is INR 6500000/-. Calculate the firm’s debtor days (round the answer to 2 decimal places).

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Utility Theory**
- **Cardinal Utility Theory (CUT)**: Measures utility in quantitative terms.
- **Ordinal Utility Theory (OUT)**: Ranks preferences without quantifying utility.
- **Total Utility and Marginal Utility**:
  - Total Utility: Sum of satisfaction from consuming a good.
  - Marginal Utility: Additional satisfaction from consuming an additional unit of a good.
  - Relationship: Total utility increases at a decreasing rate when marginal utility is decreasing but positive.

#### 2. **Indifference Curves**
- **Definition**: Graphical representation of combinations of goods that provide equal utility.
- **Axes**: Quantity of Good X and Quantity of Good Y.

#### 3. **Types of Goods**
- **Complementary Goods**: Goods used together (e.g., printer and ink cartridge).
- **Substitutable Goods**: Goods that can replace each other (e.g., Dosa and Idli).

#### 4. **Income and Substitution Effects**
- **Income Effect**: Change in consumption due to a change in purchasing power.
- **Substitution Effect**: Change in consumption due to a change in relative prices.

#### 5. **Production Function**
- **Definition**: Relationship between inputs (labor, capital) and output.
- **Equation**: \( Q = f(X_1, X_2, ..., X_k) \)

#### 6. **Pricing Strategies**
- **Customer Value Pricing**: Setting prices based on customer perceptions of value.
- **Psychological Pricing**: Setting prices based on psychological factors.
- **Contribution Pricing**: Setting prices based on contribution margins.
- **Going Rate Pricing**: Setting prices based on competitors' prices.

#### 7. **Demand Curves**
- **Shift in Demand**: Change in demand due to factors other than price.
- **Increase in Demand**: Shift to the right.
- **Decrease in Demand**: Shift to the left.

#### 8. **Price Elasticity of Demand**
- **Definition**: Measure of the responsiveness of demand to a change in price.
- **Formula**: \( E_d = \frac{\% \text{ Change in Quantity Demanded}}{\% \text{ Change in Price}} \)

#### 9. **Income Elasticity of Demand**
- **Definition**: Measure of the responsiveness of demand to a change in income.
- **Categories**:
  - Normal Goods: Positive income elasticity.
  - Luxuries: High positive income elasticity.
  - Necessities: Low positive income elasticity.
  - Inferior Goods: Negative income elasticity.

#### 10. **Financial Ratios**
- **Quick Ratio (Acid-Test)**: Measures a firm's ability to meet short-term obligations with quick assets.
  - **Formula**: \( \text{Quick Ratio} = \frac{\text{Quick Assets}}{\text{Current Liabilities}} \)
- **Current Ratio**: Measures a firm's ability to meet short-term obligations with current assets.
  - **Formula**: \( \text{Current Ratio} = \frac{\text{Current Assets}}{\text{Current Liabilities}} \)
- **Debtor Days**: Measures the average time taken to collect receivables.
  - **Formula**: \( \text{Debtor Days} = \frac{\text{Accounts Receivable}}{\text{Annual Sales}} \times 365 \)

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Utility Theory] --> B[Cardinal Utility Theory]
    A --> C[Ordinal Utility Theory]
    B --> D[Total Utility]
    B --> E[Marginal Utility]
    C --> F[Preference Ranking]
    G[Indifference Curves] --> H[Quantity of Good X]
    G --> I[Quantity of Good Y]
    J[Types of Goods] --> K[Complementary Goods]
    J --> L[Substitutable Goods]
    M[Income and Substitution Effects] --> N[Income Effect]
    M --> O[Substitution Effect]
    P[Production Function] --> Q[Inputs and Outputs]
    R[Pricing Strategies] --> S[Customer Value Pricing]
    R --> T[Psychological Pricing]
    R --> U[Contribution Pricing]
    R --> V[Going Rate Pricing]
    W[Demand Curves] --> X[Shift in Demand]
    Y[Price Elasticity of Demand] --> Z[Responsiveness of Demand]
    AA[Income Elasticity of Demand] --> AB[Normal Goods]
    AA --> AC[Luxuries]
    AA --> AD[Necessities]
    AA --> AE[Inferior Goods]
    AF[Financial Ratios] --> AG[Quick Ratio]
    AF --> AH[Current Ratio]
    AF --> AI[Debtor Days]
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics and their relationships for the exam.
